Philosophizing With Others?
5. Philosophy For Children Today

In light of the rapidly expanding international interest in philosophy
for children, the International Council for Philosophical Inquiry with
Children (ICPIC) was established in 1985. ICPIC continues to sponsor
an international conference every other year, with hosts including
Australia, Austria, Brazil, England, Mexico, Spain (twice), and
Taiwan.

Even after the passing of IAPC pioneers Matthew Lipman (2010) and Ann
Margaret Sharp (2011), now led by Maughn Gregory and others, IAPC
retains a strong presence in ICPIC. However, many ICPIC members now
have established their own institutional structures and have developed
centers, associations, and programs. In North America, there is the
North American Association of Community of Inquiry (NAACI), which
gathers every other year (years when ICPIC is not meeting). With
initial support from the American Philosophical Association’s
Pre-College Philosophy Committee, PLATO (Philosophy Learning and
Teaching Organization) was formed. Now a non-profit organization
supported by the Squire Family Foundation, PLATO sponsors annual
meetings, and in 2022 the University of Washington Center for
Philosophy for Children and PLATO were joined. PLATO also sponsors two
periodicals: Questions and the online Precollege
Philosophy and Public Practice. Australia and New Zealand are
organized under the Federation of Australasian Philosophy in Schools
Associations (FAPSA), which meets annually and publishes Journal
for Philosophy in Schools as its official journal (Burgh and
Thornton, 2016). In 1992 the Society for the Advancement of
Philosophical Enquiry and Reflection in Education (SAPERE) was
established in Oxford, England. In 2007 England’s Philosophy
Foundation was established (Worley, 2011). Since 2005, the journal
Philosophy and Childhood has been sponsored by ICPIC and the
graduate program in education at the State University of Rio De
Janeiro (UERJ). These organizations, along with many other centers and
experienced practitioners around the world, continue to support
training programs for teachers that enable them to introduce thousands
of children to philosophy, both inside and outside regular classrooms.


Although there is continued use of IAPC materials, recent years have
been marked by a proliferation of alternative teaching resources and
ways of engaging children in philosophical discussions. For years
Gareth Matthews contributed reviews of children’s stories to
Thinking, then IAPC’s official journal (even though
IAPC’s own teaching materials made no use of other
children’s literature). This inspired Tom Wartenberg (2009,
2013) to develop his highly successful pre-college philosophy program
at Mt. Holyoke College (MA), a prize winning program that is built
around classic children’s stories. His website offers a wealth
of materials on children’s literature that are designed to
provide guidance for those wishing to pursue philosophy with children.
Karen Murris was an early objector to Lipman’s resistance to
using illustrated materials (Morris, 1992). She and Johana Haynes
offer a detailed account of the philosophical importance of picture
books (Murris and Haynes, 2012 and Murris, 2016). Peter Worley, head
of England’s Philosophy Foundation has written several
stimulating books for teachers and students that make no use of IAPC
materials. Australia’s Phil Cam has assembled a variety of
stories suitable for philosophical use with children. In short, there
is a rapidly growing list of resources that show great promise for
engaging children in philosophical discussions. (See, for example,
DeHaan et al. 1995; Fisher 1998; Keen 1997; Lewis and Chandley 2012;
Lone 2012 & 2021; McCall 2009; Murris 1992, 2016; Sprod 2001, and
White 2000). Questions: Philosophy for Young People, a
periodical sponsored by the American Philosophical Association’s
Pre-College Philosophy Committee, features young people’s
writings on special philosophical topics. The first issue (Spring
2001) focused on children’s rights.

Fortunately, the internet makes it possible to keep up reasonably well
with the latest developments around the world and communicate quickly
with other educators interested in Philosophy for Children.
Unfortunately, many of these websites seem to be short-lived. However,
see the Internet Resources section below for a list of websites that
are reliable and which provide links to other useful sites.
